metadata.title: A Game-Theoretic Approach to State-Owned Enterprise Privatization in China | by Yao Yang | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A Game-Theoretic Approach to State-Owned Enterprise Privatization in China
metadata.description: China started SOE reform since the mid-1990s under a dual track of “grasping the large and letting go the small”. This means: (a) privatize small and medium SOEs at the local level; (b) restructure…

all_paragraphs: China started SOE reform since the mid-1990s under a dual track of “grasping the large and letting go the small”. This means: (a) privatize small and medium SOEs at the local level; (b) restructure (including merge, group/conglomerate, corporatize, and initial public offerings) large SOEs controlled by the central government. An important distinction to be made here is the large and the small/medium SOEs. Large SOEs are under the direct supervision of the central government. They are mostly located in strategic or natural monopoly industries (e.g. iron and metal, aerospace, telecommunication, airlines, banks, etc); while small/medium SOEs are under the supervision of the local government (mostly county and city governments, some are under that of provincial governments), locating in more market competitive industries, such as textiles, food processing, etc. Small SOEs take up around 90 percent of all SOEs by the end of 1995. Financially speaking, small SOEs generally had worse financial performances than large and medium SOEs, they carry more debt than large SOEs. According to a 1994 survey, the debt-assets ratio was 0.83 for small SOEs, compared with an average of 0.73 for large SOEs. For large SOEs, it was not until 2013 that the central government decided to change the ownership structure. Therefore, the privatization process in this paper only refers to the small/medium SOE reform at the local level.

However, the privatization process of small/medium SOE varied greatly among regions. By the end of 1996, up to 70 percent of small SOEs had been privatized in some pioneering provinces and about half were privatized in many other provinces. A general observation is that at the beginning of privatization, local government tends to privatize enterprises with lower asset values; while since banks gained more independence after a new bank law was issued in 1995, more SOEs with high asset values got privatized.

An important political and economic foundation of the local government-led privatization is “local federalism”. Local federalism means two things: first, local governments have primary authority and responsibility for their local economies; second, they are subject to hard budget constraints. Hard budget constraints mean that local government would not easily get bailed out by the central government as in the soft budget constraints, therefore they have more incentives to make financially prudent decisions. Cao, Qian, and Weingast observe a path that the hard budget constraint of local governments induces the privatization of enterprises under their supervision.

Fiscal and financial policies enabling the hard budget constraints include the followings: (a) 1994 tax reform which cleared distinction between national and local taxes; (b) value-added tax (VAT) being created, which is shared between central and local government at a fixed ratio of 75:25; (c )1995 “Budget Law” which requires the local government to have their budgets balanced; (d) change of bank supervision authority. Since 1994, central banks’ local branches were no longer under dual supervision — reporting to both the headquarters of the central government and the local government of the region in which they resided. They were only supervised by the headquarters now.

With all these being said, we have three major players here in the privatization process, the central government, the local government, and the banks. The central government can decide whether to have hard or soft budget constraints to regulate the local government. Under hard budget constraints, the central government does not bail the local government out when it has debt; also 75 percent of VAT goes to the center.

At the local level, although local government controls SOEs, banks have the power to affect the operation of the SOEs because banks make a lot of loans to SOEs due to soft budget constraints. Local government faces the choice of whether private the SOE, and banks need to consider whether to swap debts into equities. The strategic interactions among the three players give rise to equilibrium.
The result of the privatization of SOEs rests on the central government’s policy direction, profit level of SOEs, the discount factor δ and bargaining power of the bank.

So the central government makes the first move to determine whether the game is played under a hard or soft budget. Then the local government and the bank would play a repeated game: if the local government chooses privatization, the game ends; if the local government chooses to restructure, the bank can decide to whether swap debt to equity or to ask the companies to pay back loans. The game tree is illustrated below:

Assuming that A is the asset value of the SOE, and L is its debt to the bank, and A>L. γ is the percentage of the debt that the bank can ask for from the SOE if it gets restructured, and β is the percentage of the loans bank can get from SOE if it gets privatized. The relationship between γ and β is 0≤γ≤1, 0≤β<1, β<γ. The greater γ is, the greater bargaining power the bank has; β is always very small because when companies get privatized, it is very hard for the bank to trace and ask for the money. We also assume that if banks ask for debt recover, local government can only afford to pay a certain fraction, the remaining relies on the central government to bail out. We use α to denote the fraction, 0<α<1.

π the profit rate of the company if it gets restructured. λ is the discounted profit rate when it got restructured but could not get enough funding (bank asks for debt instead of swapping debt to equity). we assume 0<λ< 1.

V means the tax rate the SOE pays to the government. Although they are state-owned, they do have different accounts. The way the government gets money from SOEs is still through tax. In soft budget constraints, the local government pays a fixed amount of tax c to the central government. c is normally very small compared to the total money it gets from companies. In hard budget constraints, the central government created a “value-added tax” (VAT). It is shared between central and local government — the central government can get 75 percent of the tax, while the local government can only get 25 percent. Φ=0.75 here.

Therefore, when central government has soft budget constraints, if local bank chooses to privatize, central government only gets fixed tax every year, in a repeated game, its payoff is c+cδ+cδ^2+…=c(1-δ)^{-1}; the local government gets the asset value and it gets to collect tax every year, so its payoff should be A+(V π A-c)(1- δ )^{-1}; the bank can probably get some debt, but as stated before, its payoff is β L, which is close to 0.

If the local government chooses to restructure under a soft budget constraint, then banks would get to choose whether to swap debt to equity or to ask for money. If the bank chooses debt to equity swap, its payoff would be π L(1-δ)^{-1}; the local government’s payoff is [(A-L)π+VπA-c](1-δ)^{-1}; the central government can get the fixed tax every year, therefore its payoff is c(1-δ)^{-1}. If the bank chooses to ask for debt, then it can get some part of the loan back, its payoff is γL; local government would get the profit and tax from the company each year, and it would only pay some part of the loan, and only give fixed tax to the central, so its payoff is [(A-γL)λπ+VπA-c](1-δ)^{-1}-(1-α)γL; the central government would get the tax yearly, plus it will bail the local government out by paying a certain amount of the loan, so its payoff is c(1-δ)^{-1} - αγL. If the bank chooses a debt-equity swap, then its payoff is the profit it gets from SOE yearly, which is πL(1-δ)^{-1}; the local government can get [(A-L)π+VπA](1-δ)^{-1}; the central government’s payoff is c(1-δ)^{-1}.

If the central government chooses hard budget constraints, then the local government and the bank still get the same options, but the payoffs are different because the central government gets 75 percent of the value-added tax and it no longer bails the local government out when it is in debt. If the local government chooses privatization, its payoff is A+(1-Φ)VπA(1-δ)^{-1}, the central government’s payoff is ΦVTA(1-δ)^{-1}, the bank’s payoff is βL.
I use backward deduction to analyze the dynamic game.
The last player is the bank, so I first compare the bank’s payoffs between debt recovery and debt-equity swap under a soft and hard budget constraint, we get:
Bank’s strategy is determined by the value of E1. If E1>0, the bank would always prefer debt recovery and vice versa.
Then we move to the local government’s options. If the bank chooses debt recovery, local government’s option between restructuring and privatize under hard budget constraint is:
If E2h is greater than 0, the local government would prefer to privatize, otherwise, the local government would prefer to restructure.
Given that the bank would choose debt-equity swap, local government’s payoff comparing to privatization under hard budget is:
This suggests that given all others constant, that local government would always prefer to privatize when E3h> 0, otherwise the local government would choose to restructure.
Under soft budget constraints, the situation is similar with a slight difference in the payoff.
If the bank chooses debt recovery under a soft budget constraint, local government compares payoff between privatize and restructure, we get:
The conclusion is similar to what we get under hard budget constraints. Local government would prefer to privatize only when the E2sis greater than 0.
If the bank chooses debt-equity swap, comparing local government’s payoffs, we get:
This also shows a similar conclusion to the situation under hard budget constraints, when E3s is greater than 0, the local government would prefer to privatize, and vice versa.

For the central government, since c is close to 0, its payoff under hard budget constraints is always higher than that under a soft budget constraint, so the central government would always prefer hard budget constraints.
Using the backwardness deduction, we can get the following axioms:
Axiom 1: There exist different values of profit rate π’ and π’’ such that:

When π< π1, ask for debt recovery is the bank’s best strategy, when π< π2, privatization would be local government’s best strategy given banks ask for debt, and when π> π3, restructure would be local government’s best strategy given that banks choose debt-equity swap. We can get that π3>π1 and π2>π1. Let π’=π1, π’’=π3, we get:

This means when companies are highly profitable and banks choose not to ask for debt recovery, local government is likely to restructure companies (higher than π’’), otherwise the local government would prefer to privatize.
Axiom 2: there exist different values of discount factor δ’ and δ’’, such that:

When δ<δ1, debt recovery is the bank’s best strategy, when δ<δ2, privatize would be the best strategy for local government when the bank asks for debt recovery, and when δ>δ3, restructure would be local government’s best strategy when bank chooses debt-equity swap.

This shows that the privatization option is related to the patience of bank and local government if both parties lack patience or expect higher inflation in the future (δ<δ’), then privatization would happen.
Axiom 3: bank’s bargaining power (γ) would also determine privatization options, such that:
This showed that after 1995 bank law was implemented, banks get more independence, local government privatizes more and private companies with high asset values.
Axiom 4:central government’s determination of Φ and c would affect the equilibrium.
When c is close to 0, the central government would always prefer hard budget constraints, but when c>ΦVπA, the central bank would prefer soft budget constraints.

This is a simplified model of the complicated privatization process. There are other important issues I did not take into consideration. The first is political constraints, ideology plays a big part in determining whether to privatize or what policies should be issued. The dual-track “letting go of the small, and grasping the big” is an experiment of different ideologies. Second, privatization is also about people. Until the 1990s, China does not have social securities for unemployed people. Privatization is also called the “cracking iron rice bowl” in China. SOEs to the workers is a lifelong supply of food and all kinds of social goods. Local government when decides to privatize firms, they need to take into great consideration of the workers’ compensation and providing opportunities for re-employment. This factor also influences the process of privatization, but I didn’t include it in the model because it is a lot more complex.

The model shows us that the privatization process is accelerated under hard budget constraints and is led by the local government. Local government would be more likely to conduct privatization if the company is less profitable, or under higher inflation expectation. In contrast, if the company is highly profitable, or inflation is not expected high, local government is more likely to restructure it. However, if the bank’s bargaining power strengths, the equilibrium would change. The higher the bargaining banks have, the more likely that local government would private SOEs even they have high-value assets or profitability.
Oi, Jean, Rural China Takes Off: Institutional Foundations of Economic Reform (Los Angeles: University of California Press, 1999).

Oi, Jean and Han, Chaohua, “Political and Institutional Complementarities: Strategies of Corporate Restructuring in China,” in System Restructuring in East Asia (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2006), pp. 1–26.

Zhou, F., and Y. Shen (1997), “Letting Go Small SOEs” Is Good for Enhancing the Quality of the State Assets, In Realistic Choice: Preliminary Summary of the Practice of Reforming Small State-Owned Enterprises, China Reform and Development Report, Shanghai: Far East Publishing House
